positive.review: Great exploration game that makes you feel like John Subnautica. Beware of glitches, which can cause your equipment to go poof.

Subnautica is such an amazing game and I loved everything about it about it. I went into this game completely blind with no spoilers so as the game went on I just kept getting more and more impressed. Originally I thought this was just an underwater survival game and then it became a full on story rich experience. If you had told me at the start of this game that at the end [spoiler] you were actually on a quarantined planet that used to be run by aliens who are 10x smarter then us who were also working on a Leviathan class prototype that can speak [/spoiler] I would think you were crazy. Game play in general was also super fun, I love the physics of the game and all the different vehicles you can use through your play through. The sea creature designs were also super creative and you can tell each of them a part pretty easily. The fear factor of this game was off the charts, I'm already scared of the ocean and this game honestly made it worse, ESPECIALLY because of the Leviathans. I would highly recommend this game if you haven't been able to tell already, there are many things to do even after you've beaten the game, the game isn't super hard to 100% and it's just an overall very fun game to play.

No doubt one of the greatest games made in the underwater genreâ€”great mechanics and good storytelling. All around, itâ€™s a great game both in concept and in execution. There are some quirks with the creaturesâ€™ pathfinding AI, and there are a handful of graphics glitches, with the environment rendering in too slowly or sometimes not at all. It doesnâ€™t happen often, but it does pull you out of the immersion a little. Other than that, this game is definitely one of, if not the most, memorable underwater games I have played. Definitely my favorite game.
I love this game! Played it so many times, the second game too. Highly recommend it to anyone that love the ocean but also fears it

Phenomenal game, even better with some QOL mods.  It starts off as survival, though that shortly becomes trivial.  The mid game is exploration with some jump scares and then you find yourself in the endgame, wishing there was more.
Cute fish. Cute (sometimes scary) game. Be sure to play with the friendly fish and run away from the unfriendly ones. This game rocks.

A fantastic game with some of the best environmental and sound design in gaming. Even though it's been over ten years since the game was first launched (in early access) and seven years since the game officially released they are still updating it when needed. I feel this game is a must play for any survival, sandbox, or open world game fan and will continue to go down in history as an all time classic.
when the game starts go to the back of the ship for the best loot. Hope this helps

Oh well, where do I even start?
This game is actually one of a kind. Usually in survival games you conquer, you tame, you kill. Subnautica offers you a possibility of learning to love planet 4546B. You experience the unknown (which is scary), you learn how to coexist with your new neighbours, you learn about the planet. Views are mesmerizing, some creatures are scary, some are like puppies, some are beautiful. 
With all that said there is also a point of critique, but it doesn't change the experience - play it for sure.
However there is some bugs. You build your habitat and fishes bug through the wall and swim in your base. Sea dragon swims through walls. Also my Sea Emperor got stuck and the game just skipped a sequence for me. [spoiler]Sea Emperor just died off screen because of it and her children didn't go through portal, because they couldn't hug her?????[/spoiler]
I really appreciate that Subnautica doesn't force you to any special tempo, your character doesn't talk so you get immersed in the world - you play on your own, you discover on your own, you learn to swim deeper and deeper on your own. However it could guide a bit more, which makes it a tiny bit frustrating - had to google some things to progress. You can literally never go to some of the regions, because you don't need them to progress and game doesn't guide you to them. 
Also from getting your first prawn suit, nothing is scary anymore, beacuse you can survive literally anything, which is too op. I wish it was balanced better. 
Achievements are really easy, you do them while progressing with the game and they actually help you to progress in the game - you can always check it and get an info what to do now. However I feel like there has been wasted opportunity for some achievements - for example scanning achievements. Maybe something like "scan ghost leviathan" or "scan Sea Dragon". This kind of achievements would be thrilling, scary, a bit more difficult but also fun.
Also the equipment in PDA could be done a bit better. For me even one more slot for fast changing could be enough. 
Nontheless with all of the downsides, this game is absolutely a must play and worth it for sure. 
If you doubt yourself - should I buy it? The answer is yes. Just buy it and play it. Experience it for youself.

Subnautica A Deep Dive into Atmosphere and Tension

Subnautica is one of those rare survival games that doesnâ€™t just drop you into a worldâ€”it swallows you whole. From the moment your escape pod hits the ocean, the game establishes an atmosphere thatâ€™s as breathtaking as it is unnerving. The alien sea is vibrant, beautiful, and constantly alive, creating a sense of immersion that few games can match. Every biome feels distinct, from the serene shallows with their pastel corals to the pitch-black depths where your lights barely cut through the water and every sound makes you tense up.

What truly defines Subnautica is its ability to balance wonder with dread. Exploration is always rewarding, but never comfortable. Youâ€™re constantly aware of your dwindling oxygen, the unfamiliar noises echoing in the dark, and the lurking threats that could emerge from the shadows at any moment. This creates a persistent tensionâ€”even routine resource gathering can spark a spike of adrenaline.

The gameâ€™s progression feels natural and satisfying. As you expand your base, craft new tools, and build vehicles, the world opens up in meaningful ways, allowing you to push deeper into the oceanâ€™s mysteries. But even with better equipment, the sense of vulnerability never fully disappearsâ€”and thatâ€™s a good thing. It keeps the experience grounded and gripping.

Overall, Subnautica is a masterclass in atmosphere-driven gameplay. Its combination of immersive worldbuilding, tense exploration, and organic storytelling makes it an unforgettable journey beneath the waves. Whether youâ€™re drawn in by the beauty of the ocean or the thrill of surviving its dangers, Subnautica delivers a uniquely compelling experience.

Rating 4/5

I played this game a few years ago and absolutely loved it! I also played Below Zero and enjoyed that one just as much. Now, Iâ€™m replaying the original Subnautica in VR on the Meta Quest 3 â€” an absolutely incredible experience!

Although there is a point in the game when you are left alone and the plot stops leading you which was frustrating. The end game upgrades are unlocked too late and you don't have a need to use them. Overall I really enjoyed this game and it was nice to be scared and intriguied up until the finish scene.

Subnautica is still one of the best survival experiences out there. The atmosphere, the music, and the feeling of exploring the unknown ocean are unmatched. Every dive feels tense and exciting, and the deeper you go, the more incredible it gets. The base building is fun, the creatures are terrifying in the best way, and the story actually gives you a reason to keep pushing forward. It is one of those games that pulls you in and never really lets go.

Subnautica is widely praised as one of the most immersive and atmospheric survival games, blending exploration, storytelling, and stunning underwater visuals.

ðŸŒŠ Overview
Genre: Survival, Adventure
Setting: Alien ocean planet 4546B
Main Character: Ryley Robinson, a crash survivor
Gameplay: Exploration, crafting, base-building, and resource management

ðŸ§  Strengths
Immersive World: The underwater environment is beautifully rendered, with bioluminescent flora, eerie caverns, and diverse marine life that evoke both wonder and dread.
Narrative Depth: Unlike many survival games, Subnautica offers a compelling story involving alien technology, ecological mystery, and personal survival.
Freedom of Play: Players can choose their own pathâ€”whether focusing on building elaborate underwater bases or diving deep into the story-driven missions.
Atmosphere: The game masterfully balances serenity and suspense. Peaceful reef zones contrast with terrifying deep-sea trenches, creating emotional highs and lows.

âš ï¸ Weaknesses
Performance Issues: Some players report frame drops and bugs, especially in deeper zones or on mobile ports.
Resource Grinding: Progression can require repetitive farming, which may feel tedious over time.

PLAYTIME:
Mainstory 31h
100%        60h

Subnautica has always held a first place spot in my heart. I grew up alongside its early access days, so its world feels almost intertwined with my own history. The gameâ€™s atmosphere is unmatched as quiet, alien, and profoundly lonely in a way that feels both comforting and unsettling. The deep ocean becomes a character in itself, and every descent into the darker biomes carries that perfect blend of awe and tension that few games ever reach.

The creature design is extraordinary. Everything feels biologically plausible yet otherworldly, and the ecosystem reacts as though it existed long before you arrived. The survival loop is simple but deeply satisfying: gathering fragments, expanding your base, and slowly pushing into more dangerous areas. Each upgrade feels earned.

What once made the experience special was the constant evolution of the original game as it grew and refined itself. That history is part of why Iâ€™m disappointed in the direction Subnautica 2 seems to be heading now. The studio changes and loss of the original team have stripped away the soul that made the world feel alive.

Even so, the first Subnautica remains one of the most immersive, atmospheric games Iâ€™ve ever played. Itâ€™s a world I return to when I want to feel small, curious, and deeply connected to something vast.
Incredible vibe game.  It's like no man sky, but under water, with a better story, and much more punishing.

Subnautica is one of those rare games that feels less like playing and more like discovering an entirely new world. It drops you into an alien ocean with nothing but fear, curiosity, and the sound of your breathing â€” and from that moment, the game owns you. At first, everything is peaceful: colorful coral reefs, harmless fish, sunlight shimmering through the water. You gather resources, craft better tools, build your first little base, and start exploring deeper.

Then the ocean reminds you who's in charge.

The deeper you go, the darker and more mysterious everything becomes. New biomes feel both breathtaking and terrifying, and every dive feels like a balance between fascination and pure anxiety. Subnautica nails the feeling of wonder mixed with primal fear â€” especially when you hear something massive moving in the pitch-black water and youâ€™re not sure whether to run or freeze.

The base building and crafting progression feel natural and rewarding, and every upgrade opens new possibilities. The Seamoth, Prawn Suit, Cyclops â€” each milestone feels huge, and you never forget the first time you leave safety behind and head into the truly dangerous depths.

The story unfolds slowly but beautifully, with mystery, lore, and a surprising emotional payoff. And the soundtrack? Calm, eerie, and perfect â€” it makes the world feel alive.

Subnautica isnâ€™t just a survival game. Itâ€™s exploration, fear, creativity, and discovery blended into one unforgettable experience. It proves a game doesnâ€™t need guns or constant combat to feel intense â€” sometimes the ocean itself is enough.

If you want a game that stays in your head long after you finish it, Subnautica is absolutely worth playing.
I love the exploration aspect and the survival is great with a bit of horror makes a great game

Amazing Single-player game. I like playing it to unwind, but it is also a fairly scary game due to, well, the ocean. Great way to face your fear if you have Thalassophobia and an even better game if you don't.

Spent the first 3hrs of this game building up resources scanning everything in sight and prepping for an expedition to the aurora. Built my first seamoth and immediately got clapped by a reaper awaiting my arrival... word of advice do not go to the aurora at night. welcome to subnautica.

When thinking about purchasing Subnautica years ago I remember being weary of survival games because of the lack of quality in some of the ones I personally tried to play. Subnautica changed that view after the first time I played it. Its gameplay was so fresh to me the art style was so beautiful the environments felt so full of life. The suspense that was held first diving into unknown waters that could be filled with anything was so interesting. The story only adds on top of this, it lets you breathe, play around a bit enjoy the game to the fullest while slowly trying to guide you into the right area. It wasn't insanely hard to follow but it wasn't in your face go grind just to progress. I haven't played many other games that come close to this in pure enjoyment and I cant tell you how stoked I am for another installment coming soon. I put off writing this review for years because the praise is high already for this game, but it deserves it. Everything I've said I'm sure has been before but this game is a complete 9.5/10. Truly and genuinely The 3d survival game of all time
One of the best games i've ever played. A lot of exploration, adventures, and creating new things to survive in an alien planet.

Subnautica is great because it combines deep exploration, tense survival, and a mysterious story inside a stunning underwater world. Every dive feels risky but rewarding, and discovering new creatures, biomes, and upgrades keeps the game exciting.
Top gameplay, story, visuals and everything!

Subnautica â€” A Deep Dive into Adventure and Discovery

Subnautica isnâ€™t just a survival game; itâ€™s a masterclass in exploration, tension, and wonder beneath the waves. From lush coral reefs to pitch-black ocean trenches, every environment is teeming with life, mystery, and danger that keeps players fully immersed.

Exploration is both thrilling and rewarding. Swimming through vibrant underwater landscapes, piloting vehicles, and discovering hidden caves gives a constant sense of discovery and awe. The procedurally inspired ecosystems feel alive, encouraging curiosity and careful observation at every turn.

Survival and crafting are intuitive and satisfying. Gathering resources, building habitats, and managing oxygen and health create a tense but deeply rewarding gameplay loop. Every tool, vehicle, and upgrade expands your freedom and allows you to tackle deeper, more dangerous areas of the ocean.

The sense of progression and discovery is addictive. Unlocking new blueprints, encountering rare creatures, and uncovering the story of the planet gives long-term goals, while hidden secrets and abandoned bases reward careful exploration and attention to detail.

Visually, Subnautica is stunning. Lush underwater environments, detailed fauna, and dynamic lighting make every dive feel immersive and alive. Combined with an atmospheric, haunting soundtrack, every encounter, dive, and discovery becomes a memorable adventure.

[h3]Final Verdict:[/h3]
Subnautica is a breathtaking survival adventure that blends exploration, creativity, and tension into a seamless underwater experience. Immersive, beautiful, and endlessly engaging, itâ€™s a must-play for fans of discovery and adventure.

â€œAn unforgettable underwater adventure filled with mystery, danger, and wonder.â€

Overall Rating: â­â­â­â­â­â­â­â­â­â­ 10/10

Subnautica is a visually stunning game with settings that allow you to play however you wish. You can choose between levels of survival or play in creative mode and spend many peaceful hours exploring and building as though you were in a gorgeous virtual aquarium. It's like getting two games in one.  
 The challenge of building bases in different biomes adds replayability, however I would like to have seen more base customization, and perhaps an npc companion to help offset the loneliness that plagues most single-player survival games.
 I am pleased to have purchased Subnautica. I expect that it will become one of those games that I return to play time and time again for many years to come.

Krafton, the publisher of Subnautica, is offering employees a year's worth of salary to quit. They're using AI to replace human developers for Subnautica 2. Subnautica is my favourite game, but I won't even think of buying Subnautica 2 now

Game does not have estonian language options as advertised on the steam page. Since that was a big part of why I got the game, I'm giving this a thumbs down. 

Now, the game itself is a solid 7/10, but on principal I have to give this a thumbs down since they didn't deliver as advertised, and I primarily got the game because survival-crafting games are great for language learning practice in my experience.

I will start with saying the game is not bad, it has its moments but I would summarize is as niche.

My biggest issue with the game was the huge amount of "Fetch Quests" with a huge amount of downtime of traveling between point A > B > C and etc. I would say 30% of my gameplay was just swimming/traveling between locations. While I understand the concept of exploration but there was not much to explore, there are like a few cool places and everything else are just sunken crap.
The story is okish/niche there is nothing too special about it but nothing to pull you up as well.

TLDR - I feel the game is incomplete, the sea world feels too empty and the objectives are dull. The game is too pricey for the content it provides.

I really enjoy a good portion of this game, but I cannot recommend it solely because the late game is such a snore. leviathans lose their spook factor pretty quickly, and a majority of your time in the 2nd half of the game will be spent going back and forth for arbitrary items (tablets, especially) rather than exploring or experiencing the story.

Parent company wants to make games entirely with AI. They can shove it. Games are as much an art form as anything else. AI has no creativity. It is not worthwhile. It contributes nothing. And you know what, I don't want to consume slop. Subnautica 1 was an incredible game that was built with care and creativity from humans. Subnautica 2 they just want to shove slop down our throats and tell us that we like it. All the while firing all the developers. We deserve better than that, Subnautica deserves better than that, and the developers deserve better than that.

I really tried to like this game and I started it twice. 
First time I had no clue what the game wanted and I was new to PC gaming, so it was a hard pass after half an hour of nothing. This game is really not beginner friendly..
After that I played several base building games (for example Satisfactory and Planet Crafter) and watched several videos about how to play and what you are supposed to do. I lasted 6 hours this time. It was fun for ~4 hours, but then all kind of bad quality of life things started piling up. 
With all that feedback and so many years of development the game lacks basic things that many other games have.. For example, why can I deconstruct only certain items? Why one menu closes with one button, but the other menu with another? Usually it's pressing the same button again or exit, but not here... Stupid.
I like enjoying my gaming time, the perfect scenario is when it's fun, interesting, chill and entertaining... obviously. This game simply became boring quickly and it started pissing me off, lol. I want a nice time, not PIA.

I tried 3 times to get into this game. 

Skyrim in ocean, yes the atmosphere is great, but highly boring, i found the crafting loop too cliche, exploration loop uninteresting. Does this game provide anything else? idk
slow paced game with a focus on enviroment and atmosphere. not for me idk

Glad I bought this game back when the people backing it still had a spine.

Terrible amount of crashes for no apparent reason? [spoiler] I have built 4/5 components for the escape rocket ship [/spoiler] and ever since doing so my game freezes constantly and gets stuck in a infinte loop trying to save

An ocean full of promise, but the deeper I went, the more I wondered why everyone was screaming masterpiece. Beneath the surface is a fairly generic survival with slow pacing and long stretches of nothing. Beautiful world, sure, but eventually I just sank under the boredom.

4/10 â€“ all depth, not much substance.

In a world where almost every game saves automatically every few minutes, for some dumb reason this game does not, I think I can speak for the majority of gamers that, our brains are wired that the game just saves automatically since that has been the norm for so long now, I played for a good chunk, I quit the game and then attempt to start where I left, but I cannot, cause this game does not autosave frequently, losing so much progress I lost the motivation to continue as I lost roughly 10 hours of gameplay, pathetic, it does not help that this feature is off by default.

so actually, all i wanted was ONE singular stalker tooth. guess what. THEY R ALL UNDERGROUND. FOR SOME REASON THEY ARE LIKE SINKING BELOW THE GROUND AND ARE COMPLETELY OUT OF REACH I CANT GET ANY EVEN WITH THE SCANNER ROOM. does anyone on the evil corrupt dev team want to actually make the ground in subnautica yk, GROUND?? all i need is one tooth but no my whole day is ruined bc for some reason the floor is just a cloud except for literally all other things and items in the game????????????????????????? FIX UR GAME!!!?????? PLEASE???? U GUYS SUCK ALSO REHIRE THOSE GUYS U FIRED BC U WERE TOO GREEDY TOO NOT PAY THEM I HATE U ALL ANMD UR DUMB BROKEN Ahh GAME.
Resources difficult to find and too spread out. You are pretty much defenseless against attacks. Building mode it GLITCHY. Game is more frustrating than fun.

I very rarely write reviews, but Subnautica has to be one of the worst games I've ever played in my entire life. No tutorial, just die over and over again with zero explanation what to do or how to progress garbage game, no fun don't buy it. Wish they would give me my money back for this stupid game. It's basically dark souls underwater, highly would not recommend this game to anyone.
Let this game die. It was good in its time period, even then I do remember the bugs. Youtubers are what kept this afloat so long.

2/10
Buggy mess where you're supposed to entertain yourself. Collecting materials is really tidious and annoying, 99% of times game doesnt tell you where and how you're suppose to get certain materials, and 70% of playing you'll spend just going from point A to point B thus from base to biom to gather resources.
About bugs, it has really clumgy save system. Game can and sometimes will autosave but randomly. Here's my situation, i was grinding materials and looking for new ones, i was dehydrated and had costume that gives you water time to time, i had somewhat 50 hp from before( i got hurt like 1 hour ago and still didnt regenerated) so i started to lose hp, in desperate attempts i tried to go out and catch some fish to get at least 3-6 water(originally i was going to biom where you can eat plants), i couldnt manage to get a fish and the moment i die, i see that water is getting added in my inventory...i ALT+F4 and load the game again just to find that around 2-3 hours of my progress, grind and building was gone due to either autosave not working, or game fucking with my save files. I tried doing something with console commands but apparently they turn off achievements on your save file permanently once you save(which guess what, this time game had 0 problems with it). So i didnt bother with even finishing the game and deleted it. My advice, play raft, much nicer, less water exploration but i dont know any other replacement.
How long has this game been out for? And there is still terrain that you can get stuck in and die? What the actual f
you run out of oxygen so quickly and i try to do into deep caves but i die instantly and its not like you can upgrade your gear so the game is broken and trash you get softlocked immediately
maybe the most tedious, boring and overhyped game i have ever played

This game is fantastic.
I'm giving it a negative review because it advertises as "VR Supported" when the VR is borderline unusable.
I'm not asking for a "full" VR experience, but being able to navigate the menus and look around should work.

If your game is pitch black at areas such as the lava zone then dont listen to the morons telling you its supposed to be like that, its usually a problem with your PC`s language somehow screwing up something and causing the blackness. Set your PC/Keyboard language to EN-US and you should be able to see again.

Thanks to Retiacura for figuring it out and F you to all the people who keep yapping that its supposed to be fucking pitch black.

Parent company wants to make games entirely with AI. They can shove it. Games are as much an art form as anything else. AI has no creativity. It is not worthwhile. It contributes nothing. And you know what, I don't want to consume slop. Subnautica 1 was an incredible game that was built with care and creativity from humans. Subnautica 2 they just want to shove slop down our throats and tell us that we like it. All the while firing all the developers. We deserve better than that, Subnautica deserves better than that, and the developers deserve better than that.

I really enjoy a good portion of this game, but I cannot recommend it solely because the late game is such a snore. leviathans lose their spook factor pretty quickly, and a majority of your time in the 2nd half of the game will be spent going back and forth for arbitrary items (tablets, especially) rather than exploring or experiencing the story.

I tried 3 times to get into this game. 

Skyrim in ocean, yes the atmosphere is great, but highly boring, i found the crafting loop too cliche, exploration loop uninteresting. Does this game provide anything else? idk

I have loved this game since it first came out, but since the last patch it is unplayable! Key map re-biding does not allow use of the arrow keys! When I try to re-bind w to up arrow it says it's print screen, and same for down, left or right arrow! I am disabled and use the arrow keys for movement and have had no problem in over 360 hours till this latest August patch! Sorry but until this is fixed it's thumb down for me!

Krafton, the publisher of Subnautica, is offering employees a year's worth of salary to quit. They're using AI to replace human developers for Subnautica 2. Subnautica is my favourite game, but I won't even think of buying Subnautica 2 now

I feel like i have to like the game just because of all the hype around it. I forced myself to like it. the game is really beautiful, and I can see so much love went into it. but, I just don't. 10 hours in and I know there is so much more to the game, but what I saw after 10 hours was boring.

Game does not have estonian language options as advertised on the steam page. Since that was a big part of why I got the game, I'm giving this a thumbs down. 

Now, the game itself is a solid 7/10, but on principal I have to give this a thumbs down since they didn't deliver as advertised, and I primarily got the game because survival-crafting games are great for language learning practice in my experience.

I will start with saying the game is not bad, it has its moments but I would summarize is as niche.

My biggest issue with the game was the huge amount of "Fetch Quests" with a huge amount of downtime of traveling between point A > B > C and etc. I would say 30% of my gameplay was just swimming/traveling between locations. While I understand the concept of exploration but there was not much to explore, there are like a few cool places and everything else are just sunken crap.
The story is okish/niche there is nothing too special about it but nothing to pull you up as well.

TLDR - I feel the game is incomplete, the sea world feels too empty and the objectives are dull. The game is too pricey for the content it provides.

I really enjoy a good portion of this game, but I cannot recommend it solely because the late game is such a snore. leviathans lose their spook factor pretty quickly, and a majority of your time in the 2nd half of the game will be spent going back and forth for arbitrary items (tablets, especially) rather than exploring or experiencing the story.

Parent company wants to make games entirely with AI. They can shove it. Games are as much an art form as anything else. AI has no creativity. It is not worthwhile. It contributes nothing. And you know what, I don't want to consume slop. Subnautica 1 was an incredible game that was built with care and creativity from humans. Subnautica 2 they just want to shove slop down our throats and tell us that we like it. All the while firing all the developers. We deserve better than that, Subnautica deserves better than that, and the developers deserve better than that.

I really tried to like this game and I started it twice. 
First time I had no clue what the game wanted and I was new to PC gaming, so it was a hard pass after half an hour of nothing. This game is really not beginner friendly..
After that I played several base building games (for example Satisfactory and Planet Crafter) and watched several videos about how to play and what you are supposed to do. I lasted 6 hours this time. It was fun for ~4 hours, but then all kind of bad quality of life things started piling up. 
With all that feedback and so many years of development the game lacks basic things that many other games have.. For example, why can I deconstruct only certain items? Why one menu closes with one button, but the other menu with another? Usually it's pressing the same button again or exit, but not here... Stupid.
I like enjoying my gaming time, the perfect scenario is when it's fun, interesting, chill and entertaining... obviously. This game simply became boring quickly and it started pissing me off, lol. I want a nice time, not PIA.
